awd_titl_txt: Coherent Spectroscopy and Coherent Control of Molecules and Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Keith Nelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is developing novel techniques that use short pulses of light in the terahertz (THz) frequency range of the spectrum. The terahertz range is just above the lower-frequency microwave (or GHz) range that is used in common devices like cellphones. Magnetic resonance measurements (similar to those in magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI) can reveal key information about molecular structure and bonding, but they have hardly ever been made at THz frequencies because of technological challenges with the sources of THz light. Professor Nelson overcomes these challenges using short THz pulses generated in a simple, tabletop-sized, experimental setup to make THz magnetic resonance measurements in about one minute. Measurements of molecular and biomolecular complexes with iron or similar elements are being conducted to understand molecular structures and how they change during chemical processes. The project has broader impacts in making facile and inexpensive THz measurement available to scientific communities in chemistry, biology, and materials science with applications spanning energy harvesting to chemical catalysis to biomedical measurement.  In addition to providing training in cutting-edge spectroscopy techniques for graduate students and post-doctoral scientists, the Nelson research group also runs a unique outreach program (the Lambda Project) in which high school students come to MIT for hands-on experiments to learn about modern optics and modern materials.

The project builds on recent demonstrations of THz electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) in both the linear regime in which free-induction decays (FIDs) are measured and in the nonlinear regime in which 2-dimensional (2D) electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) is carried out. THz EPR spectra of high-spin transition metal complexes with zero-field splittings that arise from spin-orbit coupling are measured. The splittings are highly sensitive to the ligands and their configuration around the central transition metal ion. The EPR measurement can be preceded by an optical ("pump") pulse that initiates photochemical changes, with associated changes in the spin states monitored on picosecond time scales. 2D THz EPR measurements, demonstrated on the collective spin states of magnetic materials, are being extended to multinuclear organometallic complexes in order to measure spin-spin interactions between the transition metal ions, revealing detailed information about the ground and excited-state electronic structures of the complexes. In addition to these measurements in which THz magnetic fields coherently drive electron spins, the combined THz electric and magnetic field components are being used to drive both electric and magnetic dipole moments of chiral molecules in experiments that seek new methods for enantiometric separation.  Further impacts in chemistry and biology may be realized if improved enantiomeric separation can be achieved.

por.por_cntn:
This project was aimed at the use of light in the terahertz frequency range - a bit higher in frequency than the signals used in cellphones - for fundamental discoveries in molecular and materials science. We worked on generation of short, intense terahertz pulses that can exert quite a bit of control over the behavior we are studying. Recall that light is an oscillating eletromagnetic field - there is an electric field that oscillates, let's say pointing upward and then downward, and a magnetic field that oscillates, let's say pointing toward to one side then the other (perpendicular to the electric field). In one example, we used the short pulses to make molecules of water (H2O, two atoms of hydrogen and one of oxygen) in the vapor phase rotate. Water is a "polar" molecule, which just means that part of the molecule - the oxygen atom - has a slightly negative charge and the other part - the pair of hydrogen atoms - has a slightly positive charge.  When the electric field of our terahertz light points upward, it pulls the hydrogen part of H2O upward; when the electric field points downward, it pulls the hydrogen part of H2O downward. In a single cycle of the light, the electric field points up, then down, then up again. This yanks the hydrogen part of the molecule up, then down, then up again - starting rotation of the molecule, which continues long after the single cycle of our terahertz pulse is over. Our intense terahertz pulses start lots of water molecules rotating. We discovered that a small fraction of the water molecules seemed to rotate at a frequency that was slightly different from the frequency of all the others. We could see this was happening only in signals that we measured that came from pairs of water molecules, both of them rotating. What this revealed is that there exist molecule-pair complexes in ordinary water vapor that had never been seen before, even though water is one of the most thoroughly studied molecules in the universe! All around you all the time (including right now!) are some water molecule-pairs whose members are weakly clinging to each other. When one of them rotates, the negative charge of its oxygen and the positive charges of its hydrogens are noticed by the negatively-charged oxygen and positively-charged hydrogens of the partner. That affects the rotational frequency of the other. In water vapor, the molecules will ultimately separate and be none the worse for wear. But in some cases, short-lived intermolecular interactions are the prelude to chemical reactions that yield permanent products. We are now taking advantage of the exquisite sensitivity of our method to weak intermolecular interactions to look for other sorts of complexes that could involve water, sulfur dioxide, and other atmospheric constituents and pollutants. We may gain improved understanding of atmospheric chemistry through direct observations of the reactants as they start to interact, prior to forming permanent products. 

In other measurements, we use the magnetic field of our terahertz pulses to make the tiny magnetic moments (called quantum-mechanical "spins") of electrons rotate. The magnetic moments act like tiny bar magnets, and a magnetic field that points to one side then the other yanks the north-south orientation of the bar magnet back and forth, much like the way the terahertz electric field acts on the charged parts of the water molecule. The electrons on ions like iron, cobalt, and others have distinctive magnetic spin properties, so in response to a cycle of terahertz light, their spin magnetic moments oscillate back and forth (continuing long after our terahertz pulse is over) at distinct frequencies. Nearby magnetic spins can interact (much like two nearby bar magnets), changing the signals we measure! We are aiming at understanding the roles that interactions between ions play in proteins, many of which (like hemoglobin) have multiple iron and other ions. Why did nature design so many proteins with ions that are so close together that they would surely interact? For the most part, we don't know! Direct measurements of the interactions and how they change as the protein performs its functions (for example, as hemoglobin binds and unbinds oxygen in order to transport it through your bloodstream) will help us understand better how the intricate architecture of biomolecules enables their remarkable properties.

The unique new feature of these measurements is that they allow direct observations of the interactions between constituents (water molecules, biomolecular ions, and others) even when the interactions are weak and the number of interacting species is small. That can help us reveal new processes even in molecules and materials that have been studied extensively for years. In some cases it's the interactions that underlie the most important outcomes such as chemical or biochemical transformations.
